channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Dalai Lama Debacle’ Stirs Anger in South Africa
item.description: A decision by South Africa to deny the Dalai Lama a visa to attend a gathering of former Nobel laureates in Cape Town appears to have backfired in a way that is drawing increased scrutiny to China’s heavy-handed tactics.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: The Dalai Lama visiting a school with his fellow Nobel laureates Shirin Ebadi, left, and Jody Williams, in Dharamsala, India.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Newspapers, Pro- and Anti-Beijing, Weigh In on Protests
item.description: While pro-establishment newspaper editorials call on Hong Kong to clamp down on the pro-democracy demonstrations, liberal papers, like Apple Daily, sympathize with the struggle.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: Hong Kong prides itself on its press freedom, with its newspapers offering a range of views.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New Image of the Hong Kong Protests: ‘Umbrella Man’
item.description: A 12-foot figure of wooden blocks holding a bright yellow umbrella in its outstretched right hand was moved into the protest site in front of government headquarters, evoking the Goddess of Democracy sculpture installed by students in Tiananmen Square in 1989.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A new mascot for the pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong, dubbed Umbrella Man, emerged on Sunday night.

item.title: Protesters in Hong Kong Ease Sit-In Near Government Headquarters
item.description: It was unclear whether the encampments would be abandoned, even as some paths were cleared for government workers to reach their offices.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early Monday morning, some protesters camped out overnight in the Admiralty district. One student said, “I will keep coming back till the police kick us out.”

item.title: Ebola Victim’s Journey From Liberian War to Fight for Life in U.S.
item.description: What began as a joyful reunion — refugees from African civil strife seeking to rebuild their lives in America — spiraled last week into a national health scare.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN SACK
item.media:description: Parishioners, many of them Liberian, prayed for victims of Ebola during a church service in Euless, Tex., on Sunday.

item.title: Search Resumes for Missing Malaysia Jet
item.description: The first of three ships that are expected to spend up to a year hunting for the wreckage arrived in the search area in the Indian Ocean about 1,100 miles west of Australia.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Smuggled Girl’s Odyssey of False Promises and Fear
item.description: Cecilia, a 16-year-old Guatemalan seeking a better life in the United States, fell prey to “coyotes,” the smugglers who lure migrants, on a trip that devolved into outright abduction.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE and FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Unearthing a Barbarous Past in Poland
item.description: The dead here were not only victims of the Soviets and the Nazis, but also victims of Poland’s own postwar, Communist-era security forces.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: Offering Help and Hope as Ebola Epidemic Unfolds
item.description: Congregations in Clifton, a section of Staten Island with a large Liberian population, are coming together with donations and prayers for loved ones in West Africa struggling to survive the deadly epidemic.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN FEUER
item.media:credit: Robert Stolarik for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Temple of Faith Church on Staten Island, led by the Rev. Roselyn Holder-Dimerson, center, is closely watching the outbreak.

item.title: Ebola Help for Sierra Leone Is Nearby, but Delayed on the Docks
item.description: More than $140,000 worth of medical supplies have been locked inside a dented container at the port in Freetown, Sierra Leone, since Aug. 9.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chernoh Alpha Bah in Freetown, Sierra Leone, on Friday. Medical supplies that Mr. Bah shipped to Sierra Leone to help fight Ebola have sat in a shipping container for almost two months.

item.title: Tensions Surge in Estonia Amid a Russian Replay of Cold War Tactics
item.description: Questions mounted over whether Estonia and the NATO alliance to which it belongs faced the danger of a Russian push to reprise in the Baltics some of the tactics it used to dismember Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: President Toomas Hendrik Ilves of Estonia said recent Russian tactics resembled those used on the border “before World War II.”

item.title: From Tibet to Taiwan, China’s Outer Regions Watch Hong Kong Protests Intently
item.description: The demonstrators’ discontent resonates with ethnic minorities in the far west and on the self-governed island to the east.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Hong Kong Wealth Gap on Display in Protests
item.description: Dissatisfaction with a growing wealth gap in Hong Kong has helped fuel recent public demonstrations, which could shake the city’s immediate and long-term stability.
item.category: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited|ANZ|NYSE
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: A beggar at the entry to a subway station in Hong Kong. The city’s income disparity is among the highest in the developed world.

item.title: Memo From Britain: Cameron Acts Like the Front-Runner He Would Like to Be
item.description: Despite a bold speech at the Conservatives’ party convention, the British prime minister still faces a tough road to re-election next year.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron delivered a polished speech at his party conference, but faces a tough task in next year’s election.

item.title: In Brazil’s Election, Incumbent Emerges as Front-Runner but Faces Runoff
item.description: President Dilma Rousseff emerged on Sunday as the front-runner, but she failed to win a majority of the vote, opening the way for a runoff with Aécio Neves.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Nabor Goulart/Associated Press; Marcos Fernandes, via Coligacao Muda Brasil, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Brazil's president Dilma Rousseff, left, and candidate Aecio Neves, after casting their ballots in Sunday's presidential election.

item.title: Center-Right Coalition Leads in Latvian Parliament Vote
item.description: Alarmed by Russia’s intervention in Ukraine, the governing parties back closer ties to the West, while the opposition looks to Moscow for balance.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: No Clear Majority Party Emerges in Bulgaria Vote
item.description: The country faced the prospect of another shaky governing coalition as it grapples with a sluggish economy and banking crisis.
item.dc:creator: By MARIANA IONOVA
item.media:description: A man searched a list of candidates in Sofia, Bulgaria, as voters on Sunday chose a new government amid a sluggish economy.

item.title: ISIS’ Ammunition Is Shown to Have Origins in U.S. and China
item.description: An analysis suggests that ammunition transferred into Syria and Iraq to help stabilize governments has instead passed from the governments to the jihadists.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: A .50-caliber machine gun that France offered to Kurdish pesh merga forces in Iraq last month.

item.title: Bomber Kills 5 in Chechnya on a Day of Celebrations
item.description: A suicide bomber killed five police officers and wounded 12 others on Sunday in Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, at a security checkpoint near the entrance to where thousands of people were gathering for a holiday concert and fireworks, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Al Qaeda Affiliate Battles Hezbollah in Lebanon
item.description: At least 16 insurgents from the Nusra Front were killed in an attack on Hezbollah bases along a mountain range close to the Syrian border.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Somali Town Is Reclaimed From Shabab Militants
item.description: Officials said that as African Union and Somali troops moved in, Shabab fighters fled a port town used to import arms and fighters.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Pakistan’s Lessons for Turkey
item.description: Supporting extremists is always a dangerous game. Turks must act to avoid Pakistan's fate.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL M. TANCHUM and HALIL M. KARAVELI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Kenya’s Dubious Day in Court
item.description: The International Criminal Court's handling of the Kenyan case has hurt the accusers more than the accused.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL MEYER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Putinspeak in Kyrgyzstan
item.description: Russia tries to expand its influence by exporting its repressive legislation to former Soviet states.
item.dc:creator: By MASHA GESSEN

item.title: Household Debt and Signs of Drought Squeeze Economy in Thailand
item.description: The country’s farming households are expected to bear the brunt as the central bank predicts economic growth of 1.5 percent this year.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rice farmer, who cannot afford pesticides, weeding his rice paddy.
